dir-section.heading: Religion
dir-section.p: According to self-identification at the 2011 census, 85.6% of those who stated their religious adherence were Orthodox Christians (the principal jurisdiction being the Romanian Orthodox Church), 4.6% were Roman (Latin rite) Catholics, 3.2% were Reformed and 1.9% were Pentecostal. Some 0.8% of those who stated their religious allegiance were `Greek’ (Byzantine rite) Catholics, 0.6% were Baptists, and 0.4% were Seventh Day Adventists.

dir-section.heading: The Romanian Orthodox Church
dir-section.p: The Romanian Orthodox Church is organized as an autocephalous patriarchate, led by the Holy Synod and headed by a patriarch. The Patriarchate comprises five metropolitanates, 10 archdioceses and 13 dioceses.

dir-section.heading: The Roman Catholic Church
dir-section.p: Catholics in Romania include adherents of the Armenian, Latin and Romanian (Byzantine) rites.

person.person-note: Major Archbishop of Făgăraş şi Alba Iulia

dir-section.heading: Latin Rite
dir-section.p: There are two archdioceses (including one directly subordinate to the Holy See) and four dioceses.

address.verbatim-address: 510010 jud. Alba, Alba Iulia, Str. Mihai Viteazul 21

dir-section.heading: Romanian Rite
dir-section.p: There is one archbishopric-major and four dioceses.

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Arch­bishop-Major of Făgăraş and Alba Iulia

dir-section.heading: Reformed (Calvinist) Church
dir-section.p: The Reformed (Calvinist) Church has some 700,000 members. There are two bishoprics.

address.verbatim-address: 400079 jud. Cluj, Cluj-Napoca, Str. I. C. Brătianu 51

org-entry.stats: comprises about 75,000 mems, principally of Hun­garian ethnicity

dir-section.heading: Islam
dir-section.p: There are an estimated 55,000 Muslims in Romania, mostly of Turk­ish or Tatar origin.

address.verbatim-address: 900613 jud. Constanţa, Constanţa, str. Bogdan Vodă 75
